{"comments": {"id": 412, "count": 236, "talk_id": 490}, "threadId": 412, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "490", "description": "Researcher Kamal Meattle shows how an arrangement of three common houseplants, used in specific spots in a home or office building, can result in measurably cleaner indoor air.", "event": "TED2009", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Kamal Meattle: How to grow fresh air", "slug": "kamal_meattle_on_how_to_grow_your_own_fresh_air", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "424", "slug": "kamal_meattle", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Kamal", "lastname": "Meattle", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Business owner and activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/78968_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "He has spent a great deal of time in India and abroad convincing corporate leaders, diplomats, energy ministers, and other government officials that his ideas about sustainability, individual responsibility, and respect for the environment can ensure a healthier future for everyone. 'Either you are overwhelmed by the fact that there are so many problems and so many people,' says Meattle, 'or you find solutions to help in any way you can.'", "whotheyare": "With its air-filtering plants and sustainable architecture, Kamal Meattle's office park in New Delhi is a model of green business. Meattle himself is a longtime activist for cleaning up India's air.", "whylisten": "

Kamal Meattle has a vision to reshape commercial building in India using principles of green architecture and sustainable upkeep (including an air-cleaning system that involves massive banks of plants instead of massive banks of HVAC equipment). He started the Paharpur Business Centre and Software Technology Incubator Park (PBC-STIP), in New Delhi, in 1990 to provide "instant office" space to technology companies. PBC-STIP's website publishes its air quality index every day, and tracks its compliance to the 10 principles of the UN Global Compact, a corporate-citizenship initiative.

Meattle has long been a environmental activist in India. In the 1980s he helped India's apple industry develop less-wasteful packaging to help save acres of trees. He then began a campaign to help India's millions of scooter drivers use less oil. His next plan is to develop a larger version of PBC-STIP, making a green office accessible to more businesses in New Delhi and serving as an example of low-cost, low-energy office life.

"", "description": "Business owner and activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/78968_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "He has spent a great deal of time in India and abroad convincing corporate leaders, diplomats, energy ministers, and other government officials that his ideas about sustainability, individual responsibility, and respect for the environment can ensure a healthier future for everyone. 'Either you are overwhelmed by the fact that there are so many problems and so many people,' says Meattle, 'or you find solutions to help in any way you can.'", "whotheyare": "With its air-filtering plants and sustainable architecture, Kamal Meattle's office park in New Delhi is a model of green business. Meattle himself is a longtime activist for cleaning up India's air.", "whylisten": "

Kamal Meattle has a vision to reshape commercial building in India using principles of green architecture and sustainable upkeep (including an air-cleaning system that involves massive banks of plants instead of massive banks of HVAC equipment). He started the Paharpur Business Centre and Software Technology Incubator Park (PBC-STIP), in New Delhi, in 1990 to provide "instant office" space to technology companies. PBC-STIP's website publishes its air quality index every day, and tracks its compliance to the 10 principles of the UN Global Compact, a corporate-citizenship initiative.

Meattle has long been a environmental activist in India. In the 1980s he helped India's apple industry develop less-wasteful packaging to help save acres of trees. He then began a campaign to help India's millions of scooter drivers use less oil. His next plan is to develop a larger version of PBC-STIP, making a green office accessible to more businesses in New Delhi and serving as an example of low-cost, low-energy office life.

"}], "speaker_name": "Kamal Meattle", "tags": ["architecture", "cities", "environment", "garden", "science", "technology", "plants"], "title": "How to grow fresh air", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 3540572}]}
author: Kamal_Meattle;
title: How to grow fresh air

aws-transcripts.transcript: some 17 years ago, I became allergic to Delhi's air. My doctors told me that my lung capacity had gone down to 70% on it was killing me. With the help of piety Terry Andi, Learnings from NASA, we discovered that there are three basic green plants common green plants, with which we can grow all the fresh air we need indoors to keep us healthy. We've also found that you can reduce the fresh air requirements into the building while maintaining industry indoor air quality standards. The three plants are Erica Palm, Mother in law's tongue on money plant. The botanical names are in front of you. Erica Palm is a plant which removes, kowtow and converts it into oxygen. We need for shoulder high plants per person on DDE. In terms of plant care, we need to wipe the leaves every day in Delhi and perhaps once a beacon, cleaner air cities we have to grow them and very manure, which is their ill or hydroponics and take them outdoors every 3 to 4 months. The second plant is mother in law's tongue, which is again a very common plant on. We call it a bedroom plant because it converts your toe into oxygen at night and we need 6 to 8 waist high plants per person. The third plant is money. Plant on this is again a very common plant, preferably grows in hydroponics, and this particular plant removes form lt heights and other volatile chemicals. With these three plants, you can grow all the fresh air you need. In fact, you could be in a bottle with a cap on top and you would not die at all, and you would not need any fresh air. We have tried these plants at our own building in Delhi, which is a 50,000 square feet, 20 year old building, and it has close to 1200 such plants. For 300 occupants are studies have found that there is a 42% probability off one's blood oxygen going up by 1% of one stays indoors. In this building. For 10 hours, the government of India has discovered are published a study to show that this is the healthiest building in New Delhi. On Dhe, the study showed that there is a compared to other buildings. There is a reduced incidence off my irritation by 52% respiratory systems by 34% headaches by 24% longer impairment by 12%. And that's not by 9% on this study has been published on September 8 2008 and it's available on the Government of India website. Our experience points toe amazing increase in human productive ity by over 20% by using these plants Andi also our reduction and energy requirements and buildings by an outstanding 15%. Because you need less fresh air. We're now replicating this in a 1.7 5,000,000 square feet building which will have 60,000 indoor plants. Why is this important? It is also important for the environment because the world's energy requirements are expected to grow by 30% of the next decade. 40% of the world's energy is taken up by buildings currently on. 60% of the world's population will be living in buildings in in cities with a population of over 1,000,000 in the next 15 years, and there's a growing preference for living and working in air conditioned spaces. Be the change you want to see in the world, said Matt Matt Gandhi, and thank you for listening
